problems.title: 2020 A/NT 2
problems.text: Find the unique real number $c$ such that the polynomial $x^3+cx+c$ has exactly two real roots
problems.solution: Note that it is impossible to have just 2 non distinct real roots (complex roots come in pairs so only 1 complex is impossible) Thus we must have three non distinct real roots implying that two of the real roots are equal The identical real roots must be roots of the derivative function $f'(x) = 3x^2 + c$ The product of the roots in this equation are $\frac{c}{3}$ while the product of the roots of $f(x)$ is $ c$ hence $ 3$ is the other root of $f(x)$ Plugging in $x= 3$ gives $ 27 2c = 0 \Rightarrow c = \boxed{\frac{27}{2}}$

problems.title: 2020 A/NT 3
problems.text: Call a number ``Sam azing" if it is equal to the sum of its digits times the product of its digits The only two three digit Sam azing numbers are $n$ and $n + 9$ Find $n$
problems.solution:
Let $n = \overline{abc} = 100a + 10b + c$ Obviously none of the digits are 0 so $n$ and $n + 9$ are in the form of $\overline{abc} \overline{a(b + 1)(c 1)}$ ( $(b + 1)$ doesn't have a carry because it would make $b + 1$ zero) Then we have $(a + b + c)(abc) = 100a + 10b + c$ (1) 
 $(a + (b + 1) + (c 1))(a(b + 1)(c 1) = 100a + 10b + 10 + c 1 = (100a + 10b + c) + 9$ (2) 
 
 Plugging 1 into 2 we have $(a + b + c)(ac ab a) = 9$ Then $(a + b + c) | 9 \implies a + b + c = 1 3 9$ 
 
 Case 1 $a + b + c = 1$ Not possible 
 
 Case 2 $a + b + c = 3$ 
 $a = b = c = 1$ but $111$ doesn't satisfy the conditions above Case 3 $a + b + c = 9$ 
 $a(c b a) = 1 \implies a = 1 b = 3 c = 5 \implies n = \boxed{135}$

problems.title: 2020 A/NT 4
problems.text: For all real numbers $x$ let $P(x)=16x^3 21x$ What is the sum of all possible values of $\tan^2\theta$ given that $\theta$ is an angle satisfying \[P(\sin\theta) = P(\cos\theta)?\]
problems.solution:
\begin{align*}
P(\sin \theta) = P(\cos \theta) &\implies 16\sin^3 \theta 21\sin \theta = 16\cos^3\theta 21\cos \theta \\
&\implies 16(\sin \theta \cos \theta)(1+\sin \theta \cos \theta) = 21(\sin \theta \cos \theta) \\
&\implies \tan \theta=1 \text{ OR } \sin \theta \cos \theta = 5/16 \end{align*} In the latter case \[ \sin 2\theta = 5/8 \implies \tan 2\theta = \frac{5}{\sqrt{39}} \implies \frac{2\tan \theta}{1 \tan^2\theta} = \frac{5}{\sqrt{39}} \] Then 
 \[ \tan^2 \theta + \frac{2\sqrt{39}}{5} \tan \theta 1=0 \] The sum of the squares of the possible values of $\tan \theta$ is then 
 \[ \left(\frac{2\sqrt{39}}{5}\right)^2 2( 1) = \frac{206}{25} \] Adding back the 1 then answer is $\boxed{\frac{231}{25}}$

problems.text: David is taking a true/false exam with $9$ questions Unfortunately he doesn’t know the answer to any of the questions but he does know that exactly $5$ of the answers are True In accordance with this David guesses the answers to all $9$ questions making sure that exactly $5$ of his answers are True What is the probability he answers at least $5$ questions correctly?
problems.solution:
Let $\mathcal T$ denote the set of questions whose answers are true and $\mathcal F$ denote the set of questions whose answers are false If David makes $x$ questions correct in $\mathcal T$ set then he writes $5 x$ False in set $\mathcal T$ which means he writes $4 (5 x)$ False in set $\mathcal F$ This means he makes $x 1$ correct choises in set $\mathcal F$ 
 
 Together he makes $x+(x 1)=2x 1$ coreect choices We want $2x 1\ge 5\iff x\ge 3$ 
 Now the number of of making $x$ correct choice from $\mathcal T$ and $x 1$ correct choice from $\mathcal F$ is ${5\choose x}{4\choose x 1}$ 
 Therefore The required probability is $$\frac{{\sum}_{x\ge 3} {5\choose x}{4\choose x 1}}{{\sum}_{x\ge 1} {5\choose x}{4\choose x 1}}=\frac{81}{126}=\frac{9}{14}$$

problems.title: 2020 Team 7
problems.text: Points $P$ and $Q$ lie on a circle $\omega$ The tangents to $\omega$ at $P$ and $Q$ intersect at point $T$ and point $R$ is chosen on $\omega$ so that $T$ and $R$ lie on opposite sides of $PQ$ and $\angle PQR = \angle PTQ$ Let $RT$ meet $\omega$ for the second time at point $S$ Given that $PQ = 12$ and $TR = 28$ determine $PS$
problems.solution:
Firstly I claim that $RS=2PS$ 
 Proof Note that $\angle{PQT}=\angle{PRQ}$ so $\triangle{PQT} \sim \triangle{PRQ}$ Note that $\angle{RTQ}=90^{\circ} \frac{\angle{PTQ}}{2} \angle{TRQ}=\angle{PRQ} \angle{TRQ}=\angle{PRT}=\angle{PTS}$ Let $PS$ intersect $QT$ at $M$ 
 By PoP $MS \cdot MP=MQ^2$ and since $\triangle{MTS} \sim \triangle{MPT}$ we have $MS \cdot MP=MT^2$ so $MT=MQ$ 
 Since $\angle{PTQ}=\angle{PQR}=\angle{PSR}$ $\triangle{SRP} \sim \triangle{TPM}$ $\frac{RS}{PS}=\frac{PT}{TM}=2$ 
 
 So we just need to calculate $RS$ By Law of Cosines on $\triangle{RQT}$ since $PQ=RQ=12$ $RT=28$ $QT=\frac{6}{\sin{90^{\circ} \frac{\angle{PQT}}{2}}}$ and $\angle{RQT}=90^{\circ}+\frac{\angle{PQT}}{2}$ we have $\sin^2{\frac{\theta}{2}}=\frac{9}{124}$ Then $QT^2=\frac{6^2}{\sin^2{\frac{\theta}{2}}}=496$ By PoP $QT^2=RT \cdot ST$ so $ST=\frac{496}{28}=\frac{124}{7}$ and $RS=28 \frac{124}{7}=\frac{72}{7}$ so $PS=\boxed{\frac{36}{7}}$

problems.title: 2020 Team 10
problems.text: Let $ABC$ be a triangle The incircle $\omega$ of $\triangle ABC$ which has radius $3$ is tangent to $\overline{BC}$ at $D$ Suppose the length of the altitude from $A$ to $\overline{BC}$ is $15$ and $BD^2 + CD^2 = 33$ What is $BC$ ?
problems.solution:
Call $M$ midpoint of arc $BC$ and $I_A$ center of $A$ excircle By area we have $\frac{a+b+c}{2} \cdot 3=\frac{15a}{2}$ so $4a=b+c$ 
 We can calculate exradius $r=\frac{Area}{s a}=5$ using the formula $\frac{1}{r}+\frac{a}{Area}=\frac{semiperimeter}{Area}$ 
 Then by Pythagoras’ Theorem $BI^2+CI^2=33+2 \cdot 3^2=51$ and $BI_A^2+CI_A^2=33+2 \cdot 5^2=83$ so $II_A^2=\frac{51+83}{2}=67$ 
 By Fact 5 this means that $IM=\frac{\sqrt{67}}{2}$ and $M$ is center of circle passing through $B C I I_A$ 
 By Ptolemy on $ABMC$ we have $(AB+AC)(IM)=BC(MA)$ 
 Since $AB+AC=4BC$ we have $MA=2\sqrt{67}$ and $IA=\frac{3\sqrt{67}}{2}$ 
 By Pythagorean’s Theorem on $\triangle{AIF}$ where $\omega$ hits $AC$ at $F$ we have $AF=\sqrt{MA^2 r^2}=\frac{3\sqrt{63}}{2}$ 
 By tangencies of $\omega$ we get $BC=\frac{2AF}{3}=\sqrt{63}=\boxed{3\sqrt{7}}$

problems.solution: Note that it is impossible to have just 2 non distinct real roots (complex roots come in pairs so only 1 complex is impossible) Thus we must have three non distinct real roots implying that two of the real roots are equal The identical real roots must be roots of the derivative function $f'(x) = 3x^2 + c$ The product of the roots in this equation are $\frac{c}{3}$ while the product of the roots of $f(x)$ is $ c$ hence $ 3$ is the other root of $f(x)$ Plugging in $x= 3$ gives $ 27 2c = 0 \Rightarrow c = \boxed{\frac{27}{2}}$

problems.title: 2020 A/NT 3
problems.text: Call a number ``Sam azing" if it is equal to the sum of its digits times the product of its digits The only two three digit Sam azing numbers are $n$ and $n + 9$ Find $n$
problems.solution:
Let $n = \overline{abc} = 100a + 10b + c$ Obviously none of the digits are 0 so $n$ and $n + 9$ are in the form of $\overline{abc} \overline{a(b + 1)(c 1)}$ ( $(b + 1)$ doesn't have a carry because it would make $b + 1$ zero) Then we have $(a + b + c)(abc) = 100a + 10b + c$ (1) 
 $(a + (b + 1) + (c 1))(a(b + 1)(c 1) = 100a + 10b + 10 + c 1 = (100a + 10b + c) + 9$ (2) 
 
 Plugging 1 into 2 we have $(a + b + c)(ac ab a) = 9$ Then $(a + b + c) | 9 \implies a + b + c = 1 3 9$ 
 
 Case 1 $a + b + c = 1$ Not possible 
 
 Case 2 $a + b + c = 3$ 
 $a = b = c = 1$ but $111$ doesn't satisfy the conditions above Case 3 $a + b + c = 9$ 
 $a(c b a) = 1 \implies a = 1 b = 3 c = 5 \implies n = \boxed{135}$

problems.title: 2020 A/NT 4
problems.text: For all real numbers $x$ let $P(x)=16x^3 21x$ What is the sum of all possible values of $\tan^2\theta$ given that $\theta$ is an angle satisfying \[P(\sin\theta) = P(\cos\theta)?\]
problems.solution:
\begin{align*}
P(\sin \theta) = P(\cos \theta) &\implies 16\sin^3 \theta 21\sin \theta = 16\cos^3\theta 21\cos \theta \\
&\implies 16(\sin \theta \cos \theta)(1+\sin \theta \cos \theta) = 21(\sin \theta \cos \theta) \\
&\implies \tan \theta=1 \text{ OR } \sin \theta \cos \theta = 5/16 \end{align*} In the latter case \[ \sin 2\theta = 5/8 \implies \tan 2\theta = \frac{5}{\sqrt{39}} \implies \frac{2\tan \theta}{1 \tan^2\theta} = \frac{5}{\sqrt{39}} \] Then 
 \[ \tan^2 \theta + \frac{2\sqrt{39}}{5} \tan \theta 1=0 \] The sum of the squares of the possible values of $\tan \theta$ is then 
 \[ \left(\frac{2\sqrt{39}}{5}\right)^2 2( 1) = \frac{206}{25} \] Adding back the 1 then answer is $\boxed{\frac{231}{25}}$

problems.title: 2020 A/NT 5
problems.text: Let $f(x) = 2^x + 3^x$ For how many integers $1 \leq n \leq 2020$ is $f(n)$ relatively prime to all of $f(0) f(1) \dots f(n 1)$ ?
problems.solution:
The answer is $\boxed{11}$ with $n = 2^k$ working for $0 \le k \le \lfloor{\log_2(2020)}\rfloor = 11$ 
 
 Necessity is obvious as if $n = 2^e \cdot k$ for odd $k$ then $2^k + 3^k \mid f(n)$ 
 
 For sufficiency suppose that $2^{2^a} + 3^{2^a}$ and $2^{2^b} + 3^{2^b}$ share a common prime factor $p$ Then $$2^{2^a} \equiv 3^{2^a} \pmod{p} \hspace{2mm} \implies 2^{2^{a+1}} \equiv 3^{2^{a+1}} \pmod{p}$$ implying that $\text{ord}_p\left(\frac{3}{2}\right) = 2^{a+1}$ But if $p \mid f(2^b)$ then $\text{ord}_p\left(\frac{3}{2}\right) = 2^{b+1} \neq 2^{a+1}$ giving a contradiction

problems.title: 2020 A/NT 6
problems.text:
Find all pairs of integers $(x y)$ such that $x \geq 0$ and 
 \[
(6^x y)^2 = 6^{x+1} y \]
problems.solution:
The solutions are $(1 0) (1 11) (4 1215) $ and $(4 1376)$ We can look at the problem as a quadratic in $y$ let $6^x=k$ for now $$(k y)^2=6k y\implies y^2 2ky+k^2=6k y$$ $$\iff y^2 (2k 1)y+k^2 6k=0$$ The only way to have an integer solution for $y$ is to have the discriminant be an integer or $$\sqrt{(2k 1)^2 4(k^2 6k)}=\sqrt{20k+1}=\sqrt{20\cdot 6^x+1}$$ is an integer Set this equal to $m$ Moving the $1$ and factoring gives $$(m 1)(m+1)=20\cdot 6^x$$ Note that the two terms on the LHS must both be even and thus one of them must be $2\pmod 4$ Furthermore the GCD between the two terms must be $2$ We now break into cases Case 1 $\nu_2(m 1)=1$ 
 We can have $m 1=2 2*5 2*3^x $ or $2*5*3^x$ Checking the former two gives that $m=11$ is a viable solution The latter two can be manually checked using bounds Case 2 $\nu_(m+1)=1$ 
 This is exactly the same as Case 1 just replace $m 1$ with $m+1$ In this case manually checking gives us the solution $m=161$ 
 Plugging these in gives our solution set

problems.title: 2020 A/NT 7
problems.text:
Compute the positive difference between the two real solutions to the equation 
 $$(x 1)(x 4)(x 2)(x 8)(x 5)(x 7)+48\sqrt 3 = 0 $$
problems.solution: We can pair off the terms so that they are in the form $x^2 9x+c$ $$(x 1)(x 4)(x 2)(x 8)(x 5)(x 7)=(x 1)(x 8)(x 2)(x 7)(x 4)(x 5)=(x^2 9x+8)(x^2 9x+14)(x^2 9x+20)$$ Let $t=x^2 9x$ Using the quadratic formula shows that we want to find $\sqrt{81+4t}$ We need to find the real root of $$(t+8)(t+14)(t+20)= 48\sqrt{3}$$ Noting the symmetry in the constant terms and seeing the irrational part on the RHS we are motivated to let $t=a\sqrt{3} 14$ for some real $a$ Plugging this in gives $$( 6+a\sqrt{3})(a\sqrt{3})(6+a\sqrt{3})= 48\sqrt{3} \implies a(3a^2 36)= 48 \implies a(a^2 12)= 16$$ Solving this gives the solution $a=2$ so $t= 14+2\sqrt{3}$ which means our answer is $\sqrt{81+4( 14+2\sqrt{3})}=\sqrt{25+8\sqrt{3}}$

problems.title: 2020 A/NT 9
problems.text: Let $p = 10009$ be a prime number Determine the number of ordered pairs of integers $(x y)$ such that $1\le x y \le p$ and $x^3 3xy+y^3+1$ is divisible by $p$
problems.solution: First observe that the expression factors (over the integers ) as $(x + y + 1)(x^2 + y^2 + 1 x y xy)$ There are easily $p$ pairs $(x y)$ such that $x + y + 1 \equiv 0 \pmod{p}$ as for each fixed $x$ there is exactly one solution for $y$ in the given interval Write the second expression as a quadratic in $x$ so it becomes $$x^2 (1 + y)x + y^2 y + 1 \equiv 0 \pmod{p} \iff 4x^2 4(1 + y)x + 4(y^2 y + 1) = (2x (1 + y))^2 + 3y^2 6y + 3 \equiv 0 \pmod{p} $$ This has solutions iff $ 3(y 1)^2$ is a quadratic residue modulo $p$ or $0$ but this is always true since $p \equiv 1 \pmod{12}$ and thus $ 3$ is a quadratic residue modulo $p$ Each of the $\tfrac{1}{2}\cdot(p 1)$ quadratic residues give two distinct choices for $y$ and each $y$ (these are all different) gives two distinct values of $x$ (i e each $y$ gives two different values of $x$ but across all $y$ these $x$ s may be equal) If $ 3(y 1)^2 \equiv 0 \implies y = 1$ then we get $x = 1$ for a total of $4\cdot\tfrac{1}{2}\cdot (p 1) + 1 = 2p 1$ solutions here Finally we subtract out the overlap If $x \equiv (y + 1) \pmod{p}$ then $$x^2 (1 + y)x + y^2 y + 1 \equiv 3(y^2 + y + 1) \pmod{p} $$ which has exactly $2$ roots in the interval since there are $\varphi(3) = 2$ elements of order $3$ This gives a final answer of $p + 2p 1 2 = 3p 3 = \boxed{30024}$
